Research article Tuning oxygen vacancy defects in VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2−δ nanorod catalysts through La doping for selective methanol oxydehydrogenation to dimethoxymethane Naseer Ahmad Safi Writing – original draft Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Habib Ullah Writing – review & editing Software Guilin Liu Writing – review & editing Software Feng Xin Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, PR China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 PR China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of vanadium-based catalysts with a high density of surface oxygen vacancies, supported on cerium-lanthanum solid solutions with varying La contents and moderate acidity, were synthesized. These catalysts are designed to establish an optimal kinetic alignment between the oxydehydrogenation of methanol and the condensation of formaldehyde and methanol, thereby providing an efficient bifunctional catalyst for the highly selective conversion of methanol to dimethoxymethane. Methanol oxydehydrogenation to produce dimethoxymethane (DMM) and its use as a key feedstock for the synthesis of PODE3-5, an emerging diesel additive, represents a promising strategy for mitigating diesel exhaust emissions. However, achieving high methanol conversion with high selectivity for DMM remains a significant challenge at low temperatures. Herein, a La-doped ceria-supported vanadia (VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ) nanorod catalyst was prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method to create sufficient asymmetric oxygen vacancies. Diverse techniques were employed to comprehensively analyze the catalyst structure and active sites. The results indicate that the generated oxygen vacancies not only activate oxygen species but also accelerate the cleavage of O–H and C–H bonds alongside V5+ active site within the adsorbed methanol during the methanol oxydehydrogenation reaction. The VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic efficiency, achieving 81 % methanol conversion and 95 % selectivity for dimethoxymethane under atmospheric pressure and at 200 °C in a fixed-bed reactor. Keywords Methanol oxydehydrogenation Oxygen vacancies Lattice distortion La3+-doped nanorod CeO2 Dimethoxymethane Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent decades, the consumption of diesel fuel has risen significantly, with approximately 94 % of freight transportation relying on it due to its higher energy density and superior fuel efficiency [1]. However, diesel exhaust is associated with the emission of cytotoxic substances. The emissions from the exhaust gases contain significant quantities of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and particulate matter (soot), both of which adversely impact to human health and the environment. Meanwhile, air pollution in urban areas has escalated to critical levels, necessitating the implementation of more stringent emission standards by governments. In response to this environmental challenge, polyoxymethylene dimethyl ethers (PODE3-5) have emerged as a promising diesel additive or substitute, for which the production of DMM used as a potential feedstock,attracting significant attention due to their advantageous properties [2,3]. The most basic compound in the PODEn family is PODE1, commonly referred to as methylal or dimethoxymethane (DMM). Recently, a single-stage catalytic oxidation process for methanol has emerged as one of the most advanced technologies for the efficient production of DMM. However, the direct oxydehydrogenation of methanol over various catalysts has been extensively studied in numerous investigations, including FeVPW [4], Re/γ-Fe2O3 [5], VOx/TS-1 [6], V2O5-MoO3/γ-Al2O3 [7], V2O5/TiO2 [8], and SO4 2–/V2O5-ZrO2 [9]. Despite the achievement of high DMM selectivity with these catalysts in the single-step synthesis of dimethoxymethane from methanol, the rate of methanol conversion remains relatively low. Furthermore, substantial evidence has been gathered indicating a variation of several orders of magnitude in the activity of vanadium oxide when supported on non-reducible or poorly reducible oxides with a high specific surface area (e.g., TiO2, Al2O3, SiO2, etc.). Consequently, in methanol oxidation reactions catalyzed by vanadium-supported catalysts, methanol interacts with the catalyst to form oxygen vacancies and reduce V5+ to V4+ based on the widely accepted Mars − van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [10]. The subsequent adsorption of oxygen restores the oxygen vacancies and re-oxidizes the vanadium. Experimental studies comparing non-reducible and poorly reducible oxides in this reaction have shown that V2O5/TiO2 exhibits a significantly higher reaction rate than V2O5/SiO2. Kaichev and his colleagues used in situ XANES and NAP XPS to study methanol oxidation over a monolayer V2O5/TiO2 catalyst, revealing that titanium cations remain unchanged during the reaction, which indicates that the support cations do not directly participate. Furthermore, oxide supports with high reducibility may enhance electron transfer, thereby affecting the catalytic efficiency of the supported vanadia [8,10]. Consequently, cerium oxide (CeO2) is extensively employed as a catalyst support owing to its high oxygen storage capacity (OSC). This capacity is intrinsically linked to the reversible redox cycle between Ce4+ and Ce3+, with the formation of Ce3+ being correlated with the creation of oxygen vacancies [11]. Density functional theory (DFT) studies indicate that the V–O–Ce interfacial sites significantly influence the catalytic efficiency of VOx/CeO2 in methanol oxidative dehydrogenation and play a decisive role in the adsorption and activation of both O2 and methanol [12]. Recent reports suggest that the main factor influencing the redox properties and enhanced catalytic efficiency is the local chemical environment surrounding oxygen vacancies, rather than the sheer concentration of these vacancies [13]. The catalytic activity and redox reversibility of oxygen vacancy sites can be significantly modulated by tailoring the type of coordinating cations [14], bond length [15] coordination number [16], as well as the extent of lattice distortion and local environment surrounding these sites [17]. In multiple redox reaction systems, the formation of asymmetric oxygen vacancies and their enhanced catalytic oxidation efficiency have been reported [18]. Previous studies have shown that doping with low-valence cations and/or rare earth elements (La, Nd, and Pr) can induce asymmetric oxygen vacancies in ceria-based materials [19]. Notably, studies have shown that different crystal facets of CeO2 exhibit distinct capacities for forming oxygen vacancies [20]. Moreover, the exposed crystal planes of CeO2 differ according to its morphology. Numerous studies have delineated the relative abundance of oxygen vacancies and oxygen mobility in CeO2, ranking them in the following sequence: nano-rods > nano-octahedrons > nano-cubes > nano-particles [21]. These findings emphasis the critical penetration of CeO2′s structure and morphology on the abundance and dynamics of oxygen vacancies. Accordingly, tailoring the structure and morphology of CeO2 presents an effective strategy for enhancing the oxygen vacancy abundance in CeO2-based materials [22]. In this study, we successfully synthesized four distinct morphologies (polyhedras, cubes, rods, and particles) of CeO2. Upon application, the nanorod morphology exhibited superior performance (Table 3) [23], leading us to focus on this variant for further investigation. Moreover, the doping of La3+ into nanorod CeO2 was explored to increase the generation of asymmetric oxygen vacancies. The resulting materials, denoted as Ce1-xLaxO2-δ (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3), were employed as supports for vanadium, forming the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts. These catalysts were subsequently characterized to evaluate their oxygen vacancy content, reduction behavior, and the adsorption properties of methanol and O2 on their surfaces. 2 Experimental 2.1 Source of reagents Lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3⋅6 H2O, 99,99 %), Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O, 99,99 %), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98 %), Methanol (CH3OH, 99.9 %) and Ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3, 99,9%) were obtained From Shanghai Meryer Co., Ltd. Air was obtained as the oxygen source from Tianjin Dongrun Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation In this particular investigation, the chemicals employed were of reagent grade and were used without any additional purification. Four distinct morphologies, including nano-rod CeO2-supported vanadium-based catalysts, were synthesized using a one-step hydrothermal method (Figs. S1 and S2), following procedures outlined in previous studies [11]. Detailed experimental protocols are provided in the supplementary information. 2.3 Catalyst characterization To characterize the structure of the catalyst and investigate the distribution of elements and the exposed crystal facets on the surface of the catalyst, a transmission electron microscopy (TEM- JEM2100F, Japan) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM = JEMF200, Japan) were used, and elemental mapping was also collected. The textural properties of all catalysts were determined through low-temperature N2 adsorption/desorption measurements with an SSA-7000 instrument. Before analysis, the catalysts were degassed at 150 °C for 4 h and subsequently measured at − 196 °C. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed out using a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer (40 mA, 40 kV) with Co Kα radiation, operating at a scanning rate of 8°/min over a range of 20–80° 2θ degrees. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed with a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument to assess the oxidation states of V, Ce, La, and O on the catalyst surfaces. The binding energy was determined by referencing the C 1 s signal from acquisitive carbon at 284.8 eV to ensure accuracy in the measurements. Oxygen vacancies were examined using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy (Bruker A300, Germany) at 77 K, with TEMPO employed as the spin-trapping agent to enhance the signal detection and provide more accurate results. Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Labram HR Evolution (Horiba, France) system to acquire a better understanding of the formation of crystal defects caused by La doping, providing valuable information on the structural changes. The XAFS measurements of Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ were carried out on the sample at beamline 22DK100458 of Anhui Chuangpu (AC) with the data acquisition interval (−100 eV∼ +430 eV (Ce: 5723 eV)). Oxygen temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was conducted using a chemical adsorption instrument (Biaode, PCA-1200, China) to examine the surface properties of the catalyst, including its O2 adsorption capacity and related behavior under varying conditions. For studying the chemical pathways, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) data were acquired utilizing an FTIR spectrometer (Thermo iS10). The supplementary information contains specific details about these characterization and computational methodologies. 2.4 Catalytic evaluations The methanol selective oxydehydrogenation performance over VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor under 0.1 MPa pressure at 200 °C. For the reaction, 0.1 g of catalyst powder and 0.9 g of 100-mesh silicon carbide (SiC) were mixed and placed in the center of a stainless-steel reaction tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm, with both ends of the catalyst bed filled with quartz wool to ensure effective sealing and stability during the reaction. A detailed schematic representation of the experimental setup can be found in Fig. S3. Air was introduced into the reactor at a flow rate of 4.6 mL/min, which was carefully adjusted with the aid of a mass flow meter. Simultaneously, methanol was injected into the reactor by a precision pump, maintaining a constant flow rate of 0.01 mL/min. To prevent formaldehyde polymerization and the subsequent clogging of pipelines, the temperature of all tube after the preheater was meticulously controlled at 140 °C. The reactants and products at the outlet were analyzed via an online gas chromatograph (GC-2030) fitted with a heart-cut system (HCS). All the reactants and products were resolved through a PLOT Q capillary column and discerned by a flame ionization detector (FID) to provide accurate composition data, such as methanol (MeOH, CH3OH), formaldehyde (FA, CH2O), dimethyl ether (DME, CH3OCH3), methyl formate (MF, CHOOCH3) and dimethoxymethane (DMM, CH3OCH2OCH3). The evaluation of methanol conversion and product selectivity was conducted on the basis of carbon balance calculation, where the measurement of all components was performed utilizing a precise absolute determination method. Methanol conversion (XMeOH ) and the selectivity of products i (Si ) are calculated in terms of the moles amount of carbon NC in all products included DMM, MF, DME, COx. The calculation formulas as outlined as follows: X MeOH = N C N MeOH + N C × 100 % S i = n i N i 3 N DMM + 2 N MF + 2 N DME + N COx × 100 % where, NC = 3N DMM + 2N MF + 2N DME + NCOx, Si represents the products selectivity for dimethoxymethane (SDMM), methyl formate (SMF), dimethyl ether (SDME), and carbon oxides, respectively. The symbols of ni outlet are 3, 2, 2 and 1 for i corresponding to DMM, MF, DME and COx, respectively, reflecting the carbon balance for each exclusive product at the reactor outlet and their contribution to the overall reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst morphology Fig. 1 represents the morphology of bare and doped samples with different La-doping levels. Fig. 1(a)−(d) present the TEM images of the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ nanorods, while Fig. 1(e) shows a spherical nanoparticle of VOx/La2O3. Fig. 1(f) exhibits the HRTEM image of VOx/Ce0.7La0.3O2-δ sample. It was found that La doping into ceria lattice does not alter the rod morphology of CeO2 [24]. A separate La2O3 phase appeared when the La content reached x = 0.3. Additionally, the homogenous distribution of all elements in the catalyst structure was validated by elemental mapping using Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) (Fig. S4). The rod diameter and length of CeO2 were approximately 6 − 10 nm and 70 − 200 nm, respectively (Fig. S5). As shown in Fig. S6, distinct lattice fringes are clearly observable in the samples. Statistical analysis indicated that the primary exposed crystalline facets of the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ sample are the (110) and (100) facets (Table S1), with minor exposure of the (111) facet [12]. Significantly, pronounced lattice distortion was observed for VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ sample in Fig. S7 c1-c2. The yellow region represents blurred lattice fringes, whereas the red region highlights the curved lattice fringes. Previous literature frequently associates lattice distortions, including interfacial dislocations and crystal irregularities, through the generation of oxygen vacancies, which play a decisive role in altering the material’s structure. 3.2 Textural properties of catalysts The adsorption/desorption isotherm for N2 and the pore size profile of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . As illustrated in Fig. 2 (a), all samples exhibited an IV isotherm with an H1-type hysteresis loop within the P/Po of approximately 0, along with a small hysteresis loop at a higher relative pressure. The specific surface area ranged from 16 to 77.76 m2/g (Table 1 ), indicating the co-existence of intrinsic micropores and mesopores. Notably, the pore volume (0.354 cm3/g) and highest specific surface area (77.76 m2/g) were observed for the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ catalyst, indicating superior porosity. To analyze the crystal phase structure of VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted (Fig. 2). As depicted in Fig. 2(b), all samples exhibited pure cubic cerianite structure (JCPDS No. 34–0394). The diffraction peaks corresponding to CeO2 were observed at 2θ = 28.30°, 32.9°, 47.3°, 56.2°, 59°, 69.3°, 76.6°, and 79°, which align with the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) crystal facets, respectively, confirming the crystallinity of the samples [22]. For the VOx/La2O3 sample, the diffraction peaks of La2O3 were detected at 2θ = 26.2°, 29.2°, 30.1°, 39.6°, 46.2°, 52.3°, 55.5°, and 56°, corresponding to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (200), (112), and (201) crystal facets, respectively [25]. No distinct peaks corresponding to La and/or V are detected in the doped samples, implying the effective integration of La3+ cations into the CeO2 lattice. Notably, if La forms very small or highly defective clusters, they may not be detectable by XRD. This suggests that, even though distinct peaks for La2O3 or V species are not observed, small clusters could still be present, as shown in Fig. 1(f). Moreover, both La and V species are homogeneously dispersed throughout the cerium lattice in all samples, confirming a well-distributed structure (Fig. S4). Additionally, the diffraction peaks (111) of the doped ceria exhibit a slight shift toward lower angles compare to the bare ceria (Fig. S8). This shift is attributed to the expansion of crystal lattice upon Ce4+ (0.097 nm) substitution by La3+ (0.103 nm) during the formation of solid solution. The peak shift and the expansion of lattice crystals suggest the presence of lattice distortion. The degree of lattice distortion in the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts was calculated using equation (S1) provided in the supplementary information, and the comprehensive results are presented in Fig. S7. The lattice distortion values follow the order: VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ > VOx/Ce0.7La0.3O2-δ > VOx/Ce0.9La0.1O2-δ > VOx/CeO2 > VOx/La2O3 (Table 1). The lattice distortion data of the catalysts, derived from XRD peak refinement (Fig. 2 (b)), are in excellent agreement with the findings obtained from the HRTEM images, further validating the structural observations. 3.3 Catalysts surface defects Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were conducted to detect paramagnetic species and comprehensively analyze the surface defects of the catalysts (Fig. 3 ). As illustrated in Fig. 3(a), all VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ samples exhibited a distinct EPR signal at a g-value of 2.003, conforming the existence of unpaired electrons, which are likely associated with radical species (Ce3+, V4+) on the catalyst surface. In contrast, the VOx/La2O3 sample displayed no detectable EPR signals, suggesting an absence of unpaired electrons or radical species on the La2O3 surface [26]. Notably, as the La doping level in the CeO2 lattice increased, the peak initially intensified and then decreased, suggesting that La incorporation induced lattice distortion in CeO2(Fig. S7) and influenced the generation of radical species. The relative concentration of these species follows the order: VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ > VOx/Ce0.7La0.3O2-δ > VOx/Ce0.9La0.1O2-δ > VOx/CeO2 (Table 2 ). Although the EPR signal is associated with the presence of radical species, its well-established in the literature that a correlation exists between the concentration of oxygen vacancy and the presence of Ce3+ ions on the sample surfaces. Therefore, the increase in radical species observed here can be indirectly related to the presence of oxygen vacancies, as they are often associated with Ce3+ spices on the catalyst surface. These oxygen vacancies are regarded as critical promoters, as they not only activate oxygen species but also facilitate the breakage of C–H bonds alongside terminal oxygen atoms on the V5+ active sites, which are involved in the breakage of both and O–H C–H bonds in the methanol-adsorbed molecules [27]. The observed trends in the concentration of radical species suggest that La doping into the CeO2 lattice effectively enhances the formation of surface asymmetric oxygen vacancy sites (Vn+/Ce–Vo–La), thereby improving the catalytic properties of the materials. The surface defects and chemical state of VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts were analyzed using XPS characterization (Fig. 3). As shown in Fig. 3(b), the Ce3d XPS spectra were classified into five distinct doublets, which are attributed to spin–orbit coupling interactions. The peaks v0 (882.8), v (884.3), v′ (887.8), vʺ (889.3), and vʺʹ (898.1) eV, correspond to the Ce3d5/2 energy levels. Meanwhile, the peaks u0 (900.1), u (902), u′ (906.5), uʺ (907.8), and uʺʹ (916.6) eV represent the Ce3d3/2 energy levels [28]. The three doublet peaks, labeled as v-u, vʺ-uʺ, and vʺʹ-uʺʹ, correspond to the final states (Ce3d94f2O2p4), (Ce3d94f1O2p5), and (Ce3d94f0O2p6) of Ce4+ cations, respectively. In contrast, the two doublet peaks, labeled as v0-u0 and v′-u′, are assigned to the final states of Ce3+ cations, particularly Ce3d94f2O2p5 and Ce3d94f1O2p6, respectively [29]. Therefore, it may be inferred that both Ce4+ and Ce3+ ions are present and coexist on the surfaces of the catalyst. It is well established in the literature that a correlation exists between the concentration of oxygen vacancies and the presence of Ce3+ ions on the sample surfaces [30]. The proportion of Ce3+ ion was determined by calculating the integrated area (Ai) ratio as follows: (1) c Ce 3 + = I v 0 + I ( v ′ ) + I u 0 + I ( u ′ ) ∑ i ( I ( u i ) + I ( v i ) ) Where cx represents the concentration of species x, and I(y) signifies the integrated intensity of the respective peaks, a summary of results can be found in Table 2. As can be seen from Table 2, the concentration of Ce3+ in bare VOx/CeO2 is considerably lower compared to that in La-doped VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ. This indicates that VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ possesses a markedly elevated density of oxygen vacancies. The Ce3+ ion concentration in the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ samples increase progressively with the incorporation of La3+, reaching its maximum in VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ. However, the concentration of Ce3+ decreased with further increases in La3+ content. This suggests that the elevated La3+ concentration initiates a segregation process, hindering the generation of asymmetric (Vn+/Ce–VO–La) sites while simultaneously boosting the formation of symmetric (La–O–La) sites. Furthermore, earlier research have demonstrated that oxygen species at the metal-oxide interface form asymmetrical bonds with coordinatively deficient cations, resulting in significantly improved catalytic performance in oxidation reactions [31,32]. Fig. 3(c) displays the XPS spectrum of O1s. The primary peaks observed at 529.2–529.8 eV and 529.9–531.3 eV is corresponded to lattice oxygen (O2–, referred to as β) and defect oxygen or chemisorbed oxygen (O2 2– and O2 –, referred to as α) on the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ surface, respectively. Additionally, the peaks around 532.5 eV are associated with adsorbed water or surface hydroxyl species on the samples [28]. By analyzing the integrated areas of the lattice and defect oxygen peaks, the density of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalysts was calculated using the expression [OV] % = [Aα] / ([Aβ] + [Aα] + [AOH]) (Table 2) [33,34]. It was observed that the relative amount of Oα, commonly correlated with surface oxygen vacancy concentration, gradually increased with increasing La doping level from 23 to 37.8 %, before decreasing. This trend may be related to changes in the electron density of La. Hence it can be deduced that the oxygen vacancies on the surface have a greater harmony for adsorbed oxygen species. These observations indicate that the number of surface oxygen vacancy sites on VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ increases with La doping, which is in agreement with the findings from the Ce 3d XPS analysis. In Fig. 3(d), the La3d spectra of the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ samples display characteristic doublet peaks corresponding to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 states of La3+, suggesting a consistent arrangement of La3+ on the catalyst surface [35]. This suggests that when an octacoordinated Ce4+ is substituted by a hexacoordinated La3+, two asymmetric oxygen vacancies are created around La3+, leading to the formation of a cluster (Ce)3–Vo–La–Vo–(Ce)3, as illustrated in Fig. S9. In the vicinity of the oxygen vacancy, La3+ retains its original oxidation state, while Ce4+ is reduced to Ce3+, resulting in the formation of a La3+–Vo–(Ce3+)3 cluster. The oxidation state of the Ce cation is established by its overall coordination number with oxygen atoms. It is evident that as La-doping increases, the concentration of Ce3+ rises, ultimately resulting in the formation of a stable La–O–La cluster. Fig. S10 illustrates the V2p3/2 XPS spectrum for both the undoped VOx/CeO2 sample and the La-doped VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ samples. Analysis of the deconvoluted V2p3/2 spectra revealed that the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ sample exhibits the highest concentration of V4+ species among all samples analyzed (Table 2). This observation suggests that the degree of V2O5 reduction is further enhanced by the incorporation of La3+ into the support. XPS analysis indicates that the interaction between VOx species and both Ce and La components significantly promotes the reduction of Ce and V species on the catalyst surface. This improvement in catalytic performance can be ascribed to the enhanced formation of synergistic Ce3+ and V4+ species, which together contribute to boost both catalytic efficiency and stability. Notably, the concentration of Ce3+ (37.8 %) and V4+ (39.1 %) are higher in the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ catalyst, along with a greater amount of chemisorbed oxygen species (34.6 %) compared to the other samples. It is suggested that the partial reduction of Ce and V enhances the activity of methanol oxydehydrogenation. This improvement can be ascribed to the formation of additional oxygen vacancies at the asymmetric (Vn+/Ce–VO–La) sites. In contrast to the lattice oxygen in conventional metal/oxide systems, the oxygen atoms at these sites exhibit greater reactivity, thereby enhancing methanol and molecular oxygen adsorption capacity [36–38]. Raman spectroscopy was conducted to gain further insights into the quantitatively analyze the effect of La3+ doping on oxygen vacancy concentration (Fig. 4 ). As displayed in Fig. 4(a), the significant band around 440 cm–1 in the Raman spectra of all samples corresponds to the F2g mode of the cerium lattice within the fluorite-structured. Upon doping with La3+, this peak progressively redshifts to lower wavenumbers, suggesting a modification in the symmetry of the Ce − O bonding. This shift may result from the incorporation of La3+ ions into CeO2 lattice, leading to changes in the electronic structure and bond interactions [39,40]. Furthermore, the band at 549 cm–1, which intensifies as the La content increases, is assigned to Ce3+−O bonds linked to oxygen vacancy sites generated by La3+ doping. These vacancies may be associated with asymmetric Ce–O–La sites within the bulk structure and (Vn+/Ce–VO–La) sites on the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts surface. Remarkably, a prominent band at 549 cm–1 is observed in the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ spectrum, indicating a considerable density of oxygen vacancies correlated with the D mode. The number of oxygen vacancies in the sample can be quantitatively assessed using the intensity ratio of the vibrational peak at 549 cm–1 to that at 440 cm–1 (ID/IF2g). As shown in Fig. 4(b), when the La content increased from x = 0–0.3, the I549/I440 ratio initially rose from 14.6 to 41.8 before decreasing to 26.3. This result aligns with the XPS study findings indicated in Table 2. The density of oxygen vacancies in VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ is significantly higher than in VOx/CeO2, suggesting a considerable enhancement in the performance of methanol oxydehydrogenation to DMM. This improvement likely attributed to the enhanced structural and electronic characteristics of the doped catalysts. 3.4 Chemical properties of the catalyst. To precisely elucidate the local coordination environment of VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ, XANES spectra and EXAFS studies were conducted at the L3-edges of both cerium and lanthanum (Fig. 5 ). Fig. 5(a) illustrates that the white-line peak of the Ce L3-edge XANES spectra for VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ exhibits a shift to lower energy relative to pure CeO2, indicating the formation of low-valent Ce3+ [41]. The energy shift (∼ 4 eV) is most prominent at a in tolerable La concentration of 19.86 wt%, indicating that the majority of Ce4+ ions are reduced to Ce3+ ions at a La doping level of x = 0.2 wt%, which is align with the XPS results (Table 2) [42]. Additionally, a subtle shift in the white-line peak of the La L3-edge XANES spectra was observed for both VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ and pure La2O3 (Fig. 5(b)). This shift can be attributed to the distinctive coordination environments of La3+ in these substances. Furthermore, the magnitude of Fourier transforms of the EXAFS spectra for VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ in R-space, at the L3-edges of Ce and La, are shown in Fig. 5c and d, respectively. The relevant fitting curves, along with the structural model employed for the analysis, are presented in Figs. S11 and S12. Notably, the fitting curves of R-space shown strong consistency with the experimental data, highlighting the precision of the structural model employed in the analysis. Table S2 represents the quantitative curve fitting results in R-space for the Ce and La L3-edge EXAFS spectra. During the fitting process, it was assumed that La ions occupied the standard lattice positions typically held by Ce ions. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the R(Ce–O) for VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ is greater than that observed for pure CeO2, suggesting that La3+ doping induces lattice expansion. Despite the identification of two distinct regions (La–O and La–La bonds) in La2O3, the absence of a detectable La–La bond signal in VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ (Fig. 5(d)) indicates the uniform distribution of La3+ dopants or small clusters within the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ structure, which is in agreement with the XRD, EPR, and XPS results. The outcomes of the EXAFS analysis further validated the predominance of mono-substituted La–O–(Ce)3 or La–Vo–(Ce)3 sites in VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ, rather than La-rich sites. To investigate the oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of the catalysts, the O2-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) analysis was performed to better assess the O2 adsorption capabilities of the catalysts. The O2-TPD results for all as-prepared VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 6 . Desorbed active oxygen is typically categorized into three types: Oα, Oβ and Oγ. Oα species are weakly adsorbed on the catalyst surface and typically desorb at temperatures below 200 °C. Oβ species are desorb within the temperature range of 200 °C to 500 °C and are associated with chemisorbed oxygen on vacancies, as well as a portion of the lattice oxygen. Oγ species desorb at temperatures exceeding 500 °C, indicative of lattice oxygen [22,43]. In the O2-TPD profile of the VOx/La2O3 catalyst as presented in Fig. 6, no significant Oα and Oβ desorption peaks were detected, with only a minor Oγ desorption peak observed. In contrast, the O2-TPD curves of the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts (Fig. 6), almost no Oα desorption peaks were observed. However, prominent desorption peaks for Oβ and weak desorption peaks for Oγ were observed. This suggests that the O2 supply primarily relies on chemisorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen. The O2 desorption capacities of the as-prepared VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts initially increased significantly with higher La3+ doping, but then decreased as the La3+ doping level was further increased. The VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ sample demonstrated the highest amount of OAC of 314 μmol·gcat −1 (Table S3). The incorporation of La3+ into the cerium lattice results in its insertion, weakening the Ce–O bond, facilitating the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, and promoting the release of lattice oxygen and the generation of oxygen vacancies [44]. Nevertheless, as the La doping concentration rises to x = 0.3, the oxygen desorption capacity declines. It was respectively assigned to the formation of the La2O3 crystalline phase (Fig. 1(f)) and the symmetric (La–O–La) bond of La, which is attributed to the inhibition of lattice oxygen transport and its non-participation in the redox process [32]. Correspondingly, the molar ratio of Ce3+ to total Ce ions (Ce3+ and Ce4+) in the doped samples serves as an indicator of the of lattice oxygen release capacity. A higher Ce3+ content corresponds to an increased oxygen release capacity. The results obtained align with the findings from the XPS and Raman analysis, as shown in Table 2. 3.5 Catalytic activity of VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts for methanol oxydehydrogenation The catalytic efficiency of the synthesized samples was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor under identical reaction conditions. The specific catalytic activities are presented in Fig. 7 and summarized in Table 3 . As illustrated in Table 3, the conversion rate of methanol for the four types of CeO2 is higher for nano-rod morphology than the other three morphologies; therefore, we focus on the nano-rod type in the entire manuscript. However, the conversion rate for VOx/CeO2 were low, although it also displayed high dimethoxymethane selectivity. By introducing La3+ content, methanol conversion improved while maintaining a higher dimethoxymethane selectivity. With the increment of La3+ content from x = 0 to x = 0.3 wt%, methanol conversion increased from 39 to 81 %, which indicated that La3+ species has obvious impact on the catalyst’s activity in the methanol oxydehydrogenation reaction. Early studies indicated that the addition of heteroatoms into the CeO2 structure can increase the concentration of asymmetric oxygen vacancies [45]. Furthermore, the La3+ content in the CeO2 lattice generates asymmetric vacancy sites (Vn+/Ce–VO–La), where O2 binds to the oxygen vacancies, facilitating its conversion into lattice oxygen, which in turn contributes to the cleavage of C–H bonds [46,47]. Based on these insights, we proposed that the La3+ species introduced into the ceria lattice via the hydrothermal method plays also a decisive role in the first step alongside the second step of the two-step active site mechanism. It promotes O2 activation through oxygen vacancy and provides chemisorbed oxygen species, which interact with adsorbed methanol on the vanadyl bond (redox sites), thereby generating more formaldehyde. As illustrated in Fig. 7(a), comparative experiments were carried out to explore the influence of La content in the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalysts. It is evident that, during the oxydehydrogenation of methanol to generate dimethoxymethane, all composite materials demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity and sustained stability over time. However, with the increase in La3+ content, the methanol conversion rate exhibited a gradual enhancement, reaching its maximum at x = 2 wt%, which may be due to the ability La3+ to stabilize the oxygen vacancies and support redox cycling. As the La3+ content in VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ increased from 0 to 0.2, the selectivity for methyl formate declined markedly from 14 to 3 %, while the selectivity for dimethyl ether remained about 1 %. These findings indicate that when a portion of the FA and methanol molecules react on acidic sites to produce DMM through a condensation pathway, the Tishchenko reaction may also occur in parallel to produce methyl formate, which is an undesired side reaction [48,49]. However, the methanol conversion to methyl formate and dimethyl ether were effectively suppressed. Formate species are crucial intermediates in the production of methyl formate and are essential in the synthesis of formic acid [8]. Meanwhile, the selectivity for dimethoxymethane was significantly enhanced. Thereby, the incorporation of La3+ not only promotes the redox cycle and stabilizes asymmetric oxygen vacancies but also enhances the acidic properties of the catalyst, thus inhibiting the side oxidation reaction (a detailed mechanism is provided in Section 3.6). As illustrated in Fig. 7(b), the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ sample during methanol oxydehydrogenation was systematically investigated. Methanol conversion and dimethoxymethane (DMM) selectivity increased with rising reaction temperature, reaching a maximum of 81.5 % and 95.5 % at 200 °C, respectively. However, further increasing the reaction temperature to 220 °C and 240 °C resulted in a significant increase in both by-products (methyl formate (MF), dimethyl ether (DME), COx) and methanol conversions. This trend suggests that at elevated temperatures, the desorption rate of formaldehyde (FA) is more favorable than the formation rate of dioxymethylene species. Furthermore, the oxidizability and reducibility of the catalyst are further enhanced with increment of temperature, leading to a higher formation of by-products (specifically MF and COx), as methanol is thermodynamically favorable for the oxidative dehydrogenation of FA [50,51]. Additionally, the increase in temperature promotes the forward progression of the reaction in a positive direction [52]. The elevated temperature facilitated the activation of the C–H bond of FA by methanol, promoting the conversion of DMM intermediate into dimethyl ether (DME) and methyl formate (MF) [53]. As the temperature increased, a decrease in DMM selectivity was observed, while the selectivity for MF increased. The observed temperature effect indicated that the rate of methanol oxydehydrogenation to produce HCHO was more temperature-sensitive than the net rate of DMM synthesis via the condensation of HCHO with methanol. This discrepancy is likely due to thermodynamic constraints influencing the latter reaction, as no catalyst deactivation was observed (Fig. 7(c)). The catalyst stability test results are provided in the supplementary information (SI). To ensure that the catalytic system was not operating in a mass-transfer-limited regime, we performed Weisz-Prater analysis for all samples [54,55]. This analysis rigorously confirmed that our catalytic measurements reflect intrinsic kinetic behavior rather than transport limitations (see supplementary information, Experimental section 1.8 and Table S4). To evaluate the catalytic efficiency of the catalysts, this work compares the DMM formation rate with several reports on the catalytic oxidation of methanol to DMM using different V-based catalysts, as summarized in Table 4 . Notably, Sun et al [1]. were the first to perform this comparison for the gas-phase oxidative dehydrogenation coupling reaction approach. As shown in Table 4, the catalyst activity of V-based non-noble mixed-metal oxide catalysts varied over a wide range, from 0.36 to 8.4 h−1. It’s evident that both the support material and V loading significantly influence the catalytic performances. Therefore, in our study, we consistently used a V loading 5 wt%, which corresponds to a surface vanadia coverage approaching a theoretical monolayer [56]. In this work, the DMM formation rate observed for the VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ catalyst was 8.4 h−1, placing it among the highest-performing V-based materials. Moreover, the highest DMM formation rate (23.5 h−1) was achieved over a commercial iron-molybdate catalyst, which is a well-known catalyst for formaldehyde production via methanol oxidation [57]. Comparable ranges of DMM formation rates have been documented for supported noble metal catalysts, including Re (3–19 h−1) and Ru (0–26 h−1), though catalytic activity exhibited significant variation depending on the support material and synthesis methodology. Several critical challenges restrict the practical application of noble metal and commercial iron molybdate (FeMo) catalysts. First, thermal instability leads to catalyst sublimation at elevated reaction temperatures (250–490 °C), particularly affecting Re and FeMo-based systems. Second, Ru-based catalysts exhibit strong redox properties that promote significant byproduct formation (35–70 % selectivity toward MF), necessitating energetically and economically demanding separation processes. Third, FeMo catalysts undergo progressive deactivation due to molybdenum loss (MoO3 volatilization), which deteriorates their structural integrity and long-term catalytic performance [1,58]. Thus, the non-noble metal-supported V-based catalysts reported here, which efficiently generate DMM while achieving high methanol conversion via the methanol oxydehydrogenation approach. Notably, the incorporation of heteroatoms into the support significantly impacts on the redox stability and acidic properties of the catalyst. This modification also helps suppress side reactions that lead to the formation of MF and DME, addressing key shortcomings and providing a promising foundation for continued catalyst and process development. 3.6 Methanol adsorption behavior To further investigate methanol adsorption onto the catalyst surface, in-situ adsorption measurements were conducted using DRIFTS spectroscopy at 200°C, as illustrated in Fig. 8 . Previous studies have assigned the peak at 3440 cm−1 to the stretching vibration of the –OH group in adsorbed methanol [4]. Additionally, the peaks observed at 2966 cm−1 and 2848 cm−1 are correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the –C–H bonds in methanol-adsorbed on the surface and methoxy species, respectively [66]. In addition, the vibrational deformation of the methyl ether group in DMM is observed within the range of 980–1220 cm–1. This indicates the methanol interaction with the catalyst surface, leading to the generation of methoxy species, which then desorb to generate CH3O– species, thereby promoting condensation reactions [29]. The intensity of the CH3O– peak corresponding to DMM exhibited a gradual increase with prolonged reaction time. This progression indicates that methanol is initially oxidized to formaldehyde (FA) along with a small quantity of dimethyl ether (DME) on the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalyst. Afterwards, FA undergoes further oxidation to produce formic acid. Thereafter, methanol and FA engage in condensation reactions to produce DMM, while formic acid and methanol react to generate methyl formate (MF) [67]. After 10 min, the reaction stabilized, with the peak intensity remaining nearly constant, indicating the high catalytic activity of the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ catalyst. This observation aligns with the experimental findings and corroborates the theoretical predictions concerning the methanol oxydehydrogenation reaction to generate DMM through a single-step pathway. A reaction mechanism for methanol oxydehydrogenation reaction has been proposed based on the Section 3.5 and aforementioned observations, as illustrated in Fig. 9 . We propose that methanol and O2 interact with the acid-base sites on the surface of V-based catalyst through vanadyl bonds and oxygen vacancies, respectively [68]. A proton from the hydroxyl group of adsorbed methanol is transferred to the oxygen atom of the vanadyl group, forming CH3–V5+ and O2––H moieties. Subsequently, two O–H species combine and desorb as a water molecule, leading to the reduction of vanadium from V5+ to V4+. Thus, the dissociative adsorption of methanol is a heterolytic process, associated with the creation of an oxygen vacancy. These oxygen vacancies provide chemisorbed oxygen species through the activation of O2, as illustrated in Fig. 9 (step a) [6]. The vanadium oxidation state is partially reduced and rapidly reoxidized by an oxygen atom from the support (CeO2 lattice), as confirmed through XPS analysis (Table 2 and Fig. S10), which shows a direct correlation with the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+. This suggests that the support actively participates in the process of reaction [69]. then the CH3–V5+ species kinetically cleavage the C–H bond with the assistant of VOx site, forming O–H on an adjacent V5+–O2– site and an adsorbed formaldehyde (Fig. 9, step b). The molecularly adsorbed formaldehyde can undergo further transformation to produce dioxymethylene intermediates or be released as a byproduct. Alternatively, the molecularly adsorbed FA can undergo a condensation reaction over Brønsted acid (H+OL –) sites with a methanol molecules or a methoxy groups to generate adsorbed hemiformal (HF, CH3OCH2OH) on acid site, afterward the HF undergo dehydration through the C–O bond cleavage, and the another methanol directly chemisorbed on CH3OCH2 and forming a protonated dimethoxymethane subsequently desorbs and generate the (H+OL –) site [1,70,71], which is the major reaction product (Fig. 9, step c). The formation of MF is possibly either redox-catalyzed or acid-catalyzed. In the case of redox catalysis, the C–H bond of formaldehyde undergoes cleavage and then reacts with methanol to form MF, or the hemiformal intermediate undergoes C–H bond cleavage and subsequently generates MF. The formation of MF in the acid-catalyzed pathway follows the Tishchenko reaction, in which two molecules of FA couple to generate MF [48]. Additionally, the generated formate species decompose to produce carbon monoxide (CO) and carbon dioxide (CO2) (Fig. 9, step d) [8]. The chemical adsorption of O2 at the vacancy sites promotes the reoxidation of reduced V4+ and Ce3+ cations following the final stage. Table 2 illustrates that the rise in chemisorbed oxygen enhances the reoxidation of these reduced cations, leading to the production of cations coordinated with terminal oxygen atoms at the active sites V5+. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, La doping effectively modulates the density of oxygen vacancies in the VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ nanorod catalysts, resulting in a notable improvement in its catalytic activity in the methanol oxydehydrogenation to dimethoxymethane. In this process La forms an asymmetric structure with oxygen vacancies, such as La–Vo–(Ce)3. However, excessive La leads to the formation of La2O3 crystals, which cover the catalyst surface, resulting in a reduction of oxygen vacancies. The main benefit of these asymmetric clusters, in contrast to symmetric clusters (e.g., (Ce)2–Vo–(Ce)2 or clusters with multiple La3+ cation), lies in the metastable nature of both the filled and unfilled states at the oxygen positions within these clusters, facilitating the dynamic exchange of oxygen. More importantly, the interaction of V5+ and terminal oxygen atom as well as oxygen vacancies exhibited a synergistic effect, enhancing the activity of oxygen and promoting the breaking of O–H and C–H bonds in adsorbed methanol. The VOx/ Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ catalyst contains a high density of Vn+/Ce–Vo–La sites, which contribute to its superior catalytic performance and long-term stability in the methanol oxydehydrogenation reaction to dimethoxymethane. coredata.dc:description: Methanol oxydehydrogenation to produce dimethoxymethane (DMM) and its use as a key feedstock for the synthesis of PODE3-5, an emerging diesel additive, represents a promising strategy for mitigating diesel exhaust emissions. However, achieving high methanol conversion with high selectivity for DMM remains a significant challenge at low temperatures. Herein, a La-doped ceria-supported vanadia (VOx/Ce1-xLaxO2-δ) nanorod catalyst was prepared by a one-step hydrothermal method to create sufficient asymmetric oxygen vacancies. Diverse techniques were employed to comprehensively analyze the catalyst structure and active sites. The results indicate that the generated oxygen vacancies not only activate oxygen species but also accelerate the cleavage of O–H and C–H bonds alongside V5+ active site within the adsorbed methanol during the methanol oxydehydrogenation reaction. The VOx/Ce0.8La0.2O2-δ catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic efficiency, achieving 81 % methanol conversion and 95 % selectivity for dimethoxymethane under atmospheric pressure and at 200 °C in a fixed-bed reactor.
